playbookconfig/src/playbooks/host_vars/b.message:
This documentation and the validation code to support this configuration are confusing and will lead to mis-configurations.

unified should be used to define a single source of registry for all images (platform and custom) like the original design intent. It is mutually exclusive with other registries. Here it is also used to share common attributes of other registries. What does the configuration look like if adminUser of docker.io or abc.io is different that the rest?
Then change common/default would be a more suitable key. As a user, unified would mean a single unified registry source to me.

I'd be ok with changing it to 'defaults:' .
( the name semantically implies that the values can be overridden )

Just wondering what we do with 'unified',
e.g. remove it or leave it with existing behaviour
( would sort of like to remove it since don't like having tons of parameters in bootstrap )

It would be just a key name switch. The switch should be done in the back-end as well so the front end (configuration file) and back-end service-parameter-list output are consistent.

"defaults" clearly reflects configuration intent.

I would add another documentation example for a unified registry source
docker_registry:
  defaults:
    url: unified.io
    type: docker
    username: adminUser
    password: adminPass

I don't think it's confusing.

unified will now represent common values to be applied to all override-able public registries, and values under the specific registries, if specified, will take precedence over these common values.

Makes it much easier in scenarios where most attributes are common (unified) except for one or two exceptions.  ( in the old model, this would have meant all values would have had to be specified for all registries, even though only one or two items were different )

This approach was reviewed Brent and Matt.

If we cast to a crap ton of computes, then you're just asking for a DDoS of you glance. Without other knobs, the only way to mitigate that is to define smaller aggregates and throttle you requests. I don't want this to fail on details like this as the other attempts had, so I figure just being slow and doing it once-per-compute is probably the way to go (or some parallelism limit if need-be).

Again, by call here I'm not sure if you mean method or cast, but the API should definitely cast off to conductor and I think conductor should probably also cast off to compute given this could be a lot of hosts with a lot of images potentially.

The compute drivers have an "has_imagecache" capability which we could turn into a standard trait reported to placement and then if necessary we could pre-filter the hosts based on that capability trait in conductor, but that's not likely something we need to worry too much about on a first pass, nor is it likely much gain vs just casting to a compute that doesn't honor the request.

You have a nova host aggregate anyway, right? And we mirror those to placement as resource provider aggregates. So yeah I'd think if a provider in that aggregate is reporting the COMPUTE_HAS_IMAGECACHE trait we could request a list of providers from placement in the aggregate with that trait:

GET /resource_providers?member_of=<aggregate_uuid>&required=COMPUTE_HAS_IMAGECACHE

The problem with that is I'm not sure how easily that maps between compute service hosts and resource providers, since with ironic that could be 1:M (though in this case you'd always get 0 back for ironic since it doesn't support the image cache). Meaning on the nova side I'd think we'd still have to map the providers to the hosts in the aggregate to determine which to not even bother with, which is maybe possible just based on the resource provider name which is the ComputeNode.hypervisor_hostname which for libvirt/hyperv/vmwareapi is the same as the compute service hostname.

Anyway, just a thought, it could always be fleshed out more later if we cared to optimize somehow.

From L113:

 Images that are cached via this mechanism will be
 subjected to the same expiry and purge rules as 
 those downloaded on demand as a result of instance boots

 > i have not really looked too closely but how does the virt driver
 > today clean up backing files/cached iamges today.
 > does it remvoe them when the last instance on the host that uses it
 > is removed? im trying to scope the lifetime of a cached image to

 > you boot an instance that uses it or if we could end up filling up
 > the comptues with old cached images that never get used.

It excludes base images that are referenced, and then uses lifetime (with a configurable expiry timer) on the unreferenced ones.

95-97, but yeah. The collating need not be done synchronously.

doc/source/user/upgrade.rst.message:
When I've done this in devstack, I seem to remember that order matters, right? Like if I'm specifically syncing cell1, don't you need to do something like this:

nova-manage --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf --config-file /etc/nova/nova_cell1.conf db sync

Because nova.conf (in devsack) defines the api db and cell0 db, and nova_cell1.conf just defines the cell1 db (not the api db) and is used to override the [database]/connection we are syncing.

Anyway, if I'm not off the mark, that might be useful information - though arguably something to actually call out in the CLI docs for the command itself if we're going to go into details because this isn't the only place in the nova docs that mentions the db sync command, e.g. https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/cells.html

The original doc says ``nova-manage db sync`` should be run clearly. It is better to mention ``nova-manage db sync`` clearly here instead of "this" because the other command ``nova-manage api_db sync`` also is mentioned at the above.

So in devstack, nova.conf is used by the controller services at the "top" (api, superconductor and scheduler) and [database]/connection is set to cell0:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/78ec8a4854e94baab2bbddc81a5947bc/log/controller/logs/etc/nova/nova_conf.txt.gz#61

So syncing with just nova.conf in devstack will sync cell0 only, not cell1. To sync cell1, you have to provide the --config-file pointing at nova_cell1.conf which has [database]/connection pointed at cell1:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/78ec8a4854e94baab2bbddc81a5947bc/log/controller/logs/etc/nova/nova_cell1_conf.txt.gz#3

Looking at a devstack run that equates to:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/78ec8a4854e94baab2bbddc81a5947bc/log/controller/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#19900

nova-manage --config-file /etc/nova/nova_cell1.conf db sync --local_cell

and then to sync cell0:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/78ec8a4854e94baab2bbddc81a5947bc/log/controller/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#20659

nova-manage --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf db sync

My guess is that most single cell deployments still use a single nova.conf with [database]/connection configured for the cell1 database and db sync with just that is fine since it will hit cell0 and cell1, and I think that's what you're trying to say here, right?

Yeah, this patch came about as a result of tinkering with migrations on a local (DevStack-based) deployment, so that would make sense, yeah. We don't want to put DevStack-specific verbiage in here so dropping references to specific cells like dansmith suggests make sense.

Personally I'd rather not make this distinction. I'd prefer something like:

 db sync should be run for all cell databases, including cell0

or

 db sync should be run for cell0, and then all real cell databases (you have at least one of these)

The name "cell0" is kinda special, but there is nothing special about "cell1" so calling it out like this is asking for trouble/confusion, IMHO.

Note that by default db sync does sync cell0, so "including cell0" seems like it's something people have to opt into but it's actually something you would opt out of (which is what devstack does with that --local_cell flag when syncing cell1).

The CLI docs also mention this:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/cli/nova-manage.html#nova-database

"By default, this command will also attempt to upgrade the schema for the cell0 database if it is mapped"
In a multi cell environment wouldn't it be better to use --local_cell if explicitly syncing cell0, to avoid syncing it once for every cell?
As Mark pointed out in the ML thread where I called out this change, this should also mention using --config-file to run online data migrations per cell DB.
I opened bug 1846527 in case someone gets to that before me.

README.md.message:
The truth is slightly more complicated than this in multi-unit scenarios.

Given there is not a 1:1 match between leadership on principle and subordinate charm we need all the subordinates to request the migration, and only the principle leader charm will actually perform the action, while the others will just report back immediately.

We could coordinate this through leader storage on the subordinate side of the fence too so that all the units get the green light when the one subordinate unit actually connected to the principle leader gets a ack.

nova/tests/functional/compute/test_live_.message: I think we can also replace this with your spy, no?

Ah, you're right about the original behaviour bit. I see your point about making it a mock, though I'd have to look for the exact way of raising on only the *first* call - side_effect=<iterable> or whatever.

So what you need here is
* raise on the first call
* do nothing on any subsequent calls (instead of call the original)

If you know that the number of subsequent calls is N then this can be done with something like

  with mock.patch('target.func', side_effect=[CinderConnectionFailed()] + [mock.Mock()] * N):
      <do your stuff>

In the other hand if you don't know the value of N then you need a potentially infinite iterable as side_effect:

  with mock.patch('target.func', side_effect=itertools.chain([CinderConnectionFailed()], iter(mock.Mock, None))):
      <do your stuff>
This never needs to call the original behavior so I think this can be converted to a mock. The caller needs to change from stub_out() to mock.patch() though.

This is bizarre, and tbh I'm not sure how it's even working, as _spy doesn't really exist yet. Assuming it does (it must!) is it the function or the functools.partial generated by @wraps? In either case it's an odd thing to give the caller access to.

IIUC the only reason you're returning a thing to the caller is as a container for them to store stuff in, that persists from `before` to `after`. If that's the case, IMO it would be better to make a clean, empty object just for that purpose. A mock.Mock() would work, because then you can autovivify properties on it. Or even just a dict.

I think scope-wise you would need to declare it within _generate_spy but outside of _spy, so it persists across multiple invocations of the wrapped method.

And since it's important that the caller have access to the container from within the `with` context, you would have to return it along with _spy on L31 so it can be the thing you yield on L71.

>>> def f():
...     pass
... 
>>> dir(f)
['__call__', '__class__', '__closure__', '__code__', '__defaults__', '__delattr__', '__dict__', '__doc__', '__format__', '__get__', '__getattribute__', '__globals__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__module__', '__name__', '__new__', '__reduce__', '__reduce_ex__', '__repr__', '__setattr__', '__sizeof__', '__str__', '__subclasshook__', 'func_closure', 'func_code', 'func_defaults', 'func_dict', 'func_doc', 'func_globals', 'func_name']
>>> 

So even if that is partial it does not look different from a function :)

> why this works:

Yeah, I understand.

 > Sure I can create another object in the local scope of

Because the _spy function is a function (actually I'm still convinced it's a functools.partial masquerading as a function) which has properties and semantics the caller may not be expecting.

 (Pdb) dir(spy_thing)
 ['__call__', '__class__', '__closure__', '__code__', '__defaults__', 
 '__delattr__', '__dict__', '__doc__', '__format__', '__get__', 
 '__getattribute__', '__globals__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__module__',

 'func_code', 'func_defaults', 'func_dict', 'func_doc', 'func_globals',

It would take some pretty weird machinations to break it, I'll admit. But if you did do that by accident, it would be really really hard to figure out what happened.

> clean, empty object just for that purpose. A mock.Mock() would
 > work, because then you can autovivify properties on it. Or even
 > just a dict.

I played with this, and a mock.Mock() changes the way the caller has to use the thing. That might still be a reasonable option, but what I ended up with [1] is arguably cleaner (a Mock() has semantics that aren't necessarily desirable in this environment) and doesn't change the usage.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/686167

why this works:
* When the spy module is imported the body of the module is evaluated so the _generate_spy is defined
* When _generate_spy is called at L67 the body of _generate_spy is evaluated. First it defines a new function  called _spy then replace it with the return value of wraps(original)(_spy) which is still the _spy function just __name__ and __doc__ set based on original
* then _spy is returned

* when later _spy is called its body is evaluated in the enclosing scope the _spy function was originally defined in. So in the local scope of _generate_spy. In that scope _spy is defined so the body of _spy can happily access it. It is important that each and every _generate_spy defines a _new_ _spy function in its local scope and the body of the _spy function will see itself. So two _spy function bodies see two separate function objects. So they cannot interfere.

This is basically where the scope magic is moved. In the functional test cases we use a list in an outer scope[1] to store data between fake calls. Now this outer scope is the local scope of _generate_spy. 

Sure I can create another object in the local scope of _generate_spy and pass that around but why should I do that if there is already a local object, the _spy function itself.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/bf37bec80baa527ac013dfaa7480ef2761ed2cb9/nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_bug_1843090.py#L84

Another option would be to allow the caller to create its own data object. Then instead of this

 def spy_prep_resize(spy, _self, *args, **kwargs):
     # awkward:
     spy.calls_on_hosts = getattr(spy, 'calls_on_hosts', [])
     spy.calls_on_hosts.append(_self.host)
     ...

 with spy(
         compute_manager.ComputeManager, '_prep_resize',
         before=spy_prep_resize) as prep_resize_spy:

you could do something like

 tracker = dict(calls_on_hosts=[])

 def spy_prep_resize(spy, _self, *args, **kwargs):
     spy['calls_on_hosts'].append(_self.host)
     ...

 with spy(
         compute_manager.ComputeManager, '_prep_resize',
         before=spy_prep_resize, data=tracker):

It's a little bit weird that you're yielding a functools.partial object. That could have bizarre side effects if, for example, the caller tries to set its 'args' attribute.

See above...

I thin it is not a special thing I return here. It is a function. And it is the same function at every step:

('before gen returns', <function method at 0x7fe58ce58950>)
('before yield', <function method at 0x7fe58ce58950>)
('during spying', <function method at 0x7fe58ce58950>)
('during spying', <function method at 0x7fe58ce58950>)

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: This should maybe get updated, too... though as I have it now, it matches what eventlet does: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/v0.25.1/eventlet/wsgi.py#L722

it's not obvious to me *at all* that the change below should be
1) only if not py2
2) only if self.headers.get_payload()

are their good reasons to not make this stuff conditional?

I think once we've got a couple bugs with no response filed upstream on CPython's HTTP parser we're both opinionated and competent enough to just say "we're maintaining this shit ourselves" and remove a few if branches in favor of having "one preferably obvious way to do it"

As to 1, somewhere in this sad saga we started preferring that py3-only code be marked as such, to make it clear that we really aren't going to break py2. I seem to recall it in particular in the context of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/645284/ ?

For 2, the headers should have no payload -- they should have all been parsed. The fact that they weren't means that we hit the abort-parsing bug. As long as all the headers got parsed, I'm fairly comfortable saying that eventlet can take care of setting up its own wsgi.input, and we can get out of the way.

It's not obvious to me why we wouldn't want to explicitly add 'connection: close' to the headers in the else case here?  

But I trust that setting None below is sufficient i.e. the object server will get the message.

swift/proxy/server.py.message:
Please pardon my ignorance, but do we allow clients to submit a header "Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked"? I think we don't, and the above is safe, but I'm not 100% sure.

Also, W3C says (well, in a local copy of RFC-2616) that "All transfer-coding values are case-insensitive." Is this accounted? I thought we only forced case on keys of header dictionaries, but not the values.

Good call on both accounts!

We don't currently allow 'gzip, chunked' transfers, though I've played around with that idea before (usually re-writing the header after swapping out the wsgi.input). Still, better to be robust to it.

I have 2 questions:

1. Why did you not use req.is_chunked()? Issues with an exception that it can throw?

2. Do you happen to recall why exactly is_chunked() loops through headers? It does not appear to be ever called with a normal dictionary, it should be safe for it to just do [] or get().

1. If I remember right, I started with that, but as I started writing tests, I realized I hate the is_chunked() API. In particular, I dislike how it raises an AttributeError (!?) on unsupported encodings. AttributeError is supposed to *mean something* (to wit: I, as programmer, did something wrong). I thought about trying to fix that mess, but this seemed more surgical for a security fix.

2. I'm guessing because it's not really sure about case-sensitivity -- if it's only ever called with HeaderKeyDicts or HeaderEnvironProxys, so much the better.

I didn't see any tests that test this condition. Ie send a request in chunked and with a content-length and show that it's been stripped.

Unless I missed it.

doc/source/configuration/block-storage/s.message: ++ and is considered a security anti-pattern

Nice explanation here.

For additional context; keystone will validate an expired token if told to do so. Keystonemiddleware leverages this with user tokens by checking to make sure the service user has the service role defined in a service's configuration file (e.g., cinder's [keystone_authtoken] configuration section.) If those roles match, keystonemiddleware will ask keystone to validate a user's token with the ?allow_expired query parameter set (you can find all the nitty gritty details in ksm [0].)

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/src/branch/master/keystonemiddleware/auth_token/__init__.py#L373-L404
Thanks for the explanation, it's helpful to me to have a better understanding of how this is designed.  (This seems to be TMI for the doc, though.)

Interesting - I had no idea services needed to roll out their own configuration option to get this stuff to work.

I was under the impression services (like cinder) would build clients using the user information from ``cinder.conf [keystone_authtoken]`` which would be the service user.

I built a copy of the cinder.conf today and this option doesn't render, is it included? I'm working from 48f9425d2cdaa2d38f30d77b19115a64ac360c3a

I don't know that we *have to* roll out our own config, but Cinder has a specific service_auth module to handle this, and it specifically loads the info from the [service_user] group in the config file.

Shouldn't this already be in included by using ksm since it uses and loads keystoneauth's configuration options? You might be able to get access to this same information by querying ``cinder.conf [keystone_authtoken]``.

https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/src/branch/master/keystonemiddleware/auth_token/_opts.py#L193-L195
https://opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth/src/branch/master/keystoneauth1/loading/__init__.py#L25
https://opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth/src/branch/master/keystoneauth1/loading/conf.py#L30-L42

The code could probably be refactored to eliminate the Cinder [service_user] option group (as you suggested in the previous comment), but what I'd like to do is land this doc patch as-is, since it will explain how to get this to work in the stable branches, and then look into making this automatic as a follow-up.
